summary: This is a DOJ OIG interview transcript of a Federal Bureau of Prisons electronics technician regarding the camera system at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York around the time of Jeffrey Epstein's death. The interview focuses on camera malfunctions, upgrade contracts, storage issues, and access to video recording systems.

persons.name: Jesse Epstein
persons.context: The inmate whose death is the subject of the OIG investigation. The interview discusses the camera system status on the date of his death.

persons.name: Kim Simon

persons.context: Main contact for the MCC camera upgrade project from vendor SigNet. Discussed shipping delays and camera model issues via email.

Houston emailed Pridemore about getting the 'all-clear' to order cameras for the MCC project.

events.title: Camera System Failure Identified
events.description: SIS Lieutenant discovered the NiceVision camera system was not recording and could not retrieve video footage from any cameras in the institution.

events.title: Epstein's Last Phone Call
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein made a phone call from the SHU housing unit (caller station 6134) lasting approximately 21 minutes.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died in custody at the MCC. The interview examines camera system status leading up to this date.

events.title: Camera Upgrade Contract Award
events.description: Effective date for the SigNet contract (GS-07F-0322T) to upgrade the MCC camera system.

events.title: Camera Equipment Delivery
events.description: Most of the initial camera upgrade equipment (recorders, rack, UPS) was delivered to MCC, according to SigNet tracking.

keyFacts: The witness, a BOP electronics technician, stated the cameras at MCC were 'always working' but there were issues with recording and retrieving video footage prior to Epstein's death.
The camera upgrade was significantly delayed due to logistical issues (nowhere to store 300+ cameras), approval problems with camera models, and lack of authorized personnel to sign for deliveries.
SigNet, the contractor, did not ship the new cameras until after Epstein's death in August 2019, despite the contract being awarded in September 2018.
The witness had no key to the DVR/recorder room prior to Epstein's death; access was controlled by SIS staff, which complicated fixing system issues.
The wiring infrastructure for the new camera system was incomplete at the time of Epstein's death, with only one housing unit fully piped for installation.
